briefing.opening: Good morning/afternoon, everyone. I will begin the climate briefing for January 26, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Domestic Climate Change Response Efforts and Challenges
sections.content: Domestic companies and local governments are actively continuing their efforts to address climate change. Hyundai Steel, as the only domestic steel company, achieved a 'Leadership A-' rating in the CDP Climate Change Response assessment, setting an example for carbon-neutral transition [2, 4, 6, 8, 19, 26]. Yeosu City and Cheongju City are leading carbon reduction in their communities through carbon-neutral point systems and support for zero-emission vehicles [3, 34, 39, 50], and major companies like Hyundai Motor, which has embarked on research into carbon-neutral core technologies with UCL, are accelerating their eco-friendly transitions, recognizing carbon neutrality as a matter of survival [52, 56]. However, alongside criticisms that small-scale measures like banning plastic straws have limitations in solving the greenhouse gas problem, there is a growing demand for more fundamental climate responsibility from businesses and the government [1]. Furthermore, the era where carbon offset mechanisms, once called 'carbon receipts,' can no longer serve as a free pass has arrived, emphasizing the importance of companies' tangible reduction efforts [53].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Expansion of Renewable Energy and Policy Dilemmas
sections.content: Domestic efforts for renewable energy transition are yielding tangible results. In Jeju Island, 'RE100 Tangerines,' produced with 100% renewable energy, were launched for the first time nationwide, demonstrating energy innovation in the primary industry [59, 60, 63, 74, 81, 84, 87]. The government is promoting the expansion of renewable energy and enhancing the solar power supply and demand management system [61], and the Korea Electrical Safety Corporation is supporting the revitalization of the renewable energy industry by lowering inspection thresholds for wind power generation and strengthening safety [66, 83]. However, the Ministry of Climate has announced its plan to proceed with the construction of two large nuclear power plants as scheduled and to operate the power system primarily with renewable energy and nuclear power, leading to ongoing discussions about the direction of energy transition policies [42, 65, 75, 76, 85, 86]. Particularly in the Gwangju and Jeonnam regions, private solar power companies and civic groups are strongly protesting the permission for Korea Electric Power Corporation (KEPCO) to participate in renewable energy generation projects, calling it 'monopolistic favoritism' [62, 72, 78], indicating that the challenge of creating a fair market competitive environment remains.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Global Climate Crisis Warning Signs
sections.content: Severe impacts of climate change are being detected across the globe, serving as warning signs that threaten humanity's future. According to domestic and international research, phenomena such as marine heatwaves and groundwater depletion are prominently appearing [10], and the 'historic winter storms' that swept across the United States and Europe demonstrate a paradoxical disaster exacerbated by climate change [17]. In particular, the proliferation of plastic islands is raising concerns that it is eroding the 'golden time' for achieving carbon neutrality [41]. Internationally, climate change is threatening the future of the Winter Olympics [90], and some countries like Zambia, Zimbabwe, and Malawi are facing international criticism for pursuing hydropower projects on drying rivers, ignoring the risks of climate change [91]. These series of events clearly demonstrate that the climate crisis is no longer a distant future concern but a severe, ongoing problem.

sections.title: ğŸŒ Accelerating International Renewable Energy Transition
sections.content: The international community is accelerating its transition to renewable energy to combat climate change. The European Union (EU) announced that renewable energy generation has historically surpassed fossil fuel generation for the first time, marking a significant milestone in energy transition [67]. Furthermore, European nations have strengthened their wind power commitments through a 100 GW pledge, expressing a strong will to expand renewable energy [93]. The Netherlands is also exploring various energy solutions, including giving the 'green light' to the introduction of Rolls-Royce SMRs (Small Modular Reactors) to accelerate carbon neutrality [48]. These international movements suggest that renewable energy and low-carbon technologies will be key drivers of future energy systems, serving as a positive signal for achieving global carbon neutrality goals.

briefing.closing: Today's briefing has highlighted various domestic and international efforts to address climate change, while simultaneously revealing numerous outstanding challenges and urgent crisis situations. This is a time when more robust and practical actions are required for humanity's sustainable future. This concludes today's climate briefing.

articles.description: Jeju Governor Oh Young-hoon participated in the installation of film-type solar modules at the Jeju Agricultural Research and Extension Services' Tangerine RE100 production demonstration project site in July last year. (Provided by Jeju Province) 'RE100 Tangerines,' produced in Jeju using 100% renewable energy without any fossil fuels, are being launched in the market for the first time nationwide. With the implementation of a clean energy agriculture model in the fruit sector, following livestock products like eggs and milk, Jeju's carbon neutrality policy is expanding to agriculture...

summary.phenomenon: In July last year, film-type solar modules were installed at the Jeju Agricultural Research and Extension Services' Tangerine RE100 production demonstration project site, and 'RE100 Tangerines,' produced using 100% renewable energy without any fossil fuels, are being launched in the market for the first time nationwide.
